intro: Fraxinus americana subsp. texensis, commonly known as Texas ash, is a deciduous tree native to the southern United States. It typically grows to a height of 15–30 meters and has opposite, simple, and ovate to elliptic leaves. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in catkins, followed by samaroid fruits that are dispersed by wind. Its bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age. This subspecies is adapted to a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained soils and full sun.
